deliberation: Looked for non-literal expressions. The clause 'the word of YHWH came to me' uses spatial motion ('came') for an intangible message and treats 'word' as a quasi-object, a conventional prophetic metaphor/metonymy for revelation.

deliberation: Checked the vocative, the label 'rebellious house', and the sensory language. deliberation: Looked at 'son of man', 'gear for exile', and 'rebellious house'. The sign-act instructions themselves are literal actions but symbolically meaningful; the main figurative elements are the idiomatic address 'son of man' and the metaphor 'rebellious house', repeated from v.2.

instances.english_text: And you, O mortal (lit. 'son of man')

deliberation: Checked whether the exile-gear instructions are purely literal. The key non-literal marker is the comparative כ in 'as those going into exile', which indicates a simile: Ezekiel is to act in the manner of exiles, not because he is literally being deported at that moment but to resemble them.

instances.english_text: as one who goes out into exile

instances.explanation: By commanding Ezekiel to go out 'as one going into exile', the text explicitly casts his movements as a simile, a visible likeness to future deportees.

deliberation: Considered whether digging through the wall could be figurative. Here it is a literal action described straightforwardly, though symbolically meaningful in the larger narrative. No explicit metaphorical or idiomatic expressions in the wording itself.

Examined the darkness and covering of the face; these are literal within the sign-act. The explicit figurative expression is 'I have made you a מוֹפֵת (portent/sign) to the house of Israel', which metaphorically casts the prophet himself as a sign-object.

instances.english_text: for I make you a portent to the House of Israel

deliberation: This verse narrates Ezekiel’s literal obedience to the sign-act instructions: taking out his gear, digging through the wall, carrying it on his shoulder. The language is straightforwardly descriptive; the symbolic force lies in the action, not in figurative turns of phrase.
Again evaluated the prophetic formula. 'The word of YHWH came to me in the morning' repeats the same metaphor/metonymy of a 'word' that travels to the prophet.

deliberation: Considered 'son of man' and 'rebellious house' again; both reappear, as does 'house of Israel'. These are figurative; the question 'What are you doing?' is literal.

deliberation: The description of the prince’s escape attempt—carrying gear, going in the dark, breaking through the wall, covering his face so as not to see the land—matches the literal historical fate of Zedekiah. deliberation: Same prophetic formula occurs: 'the word of YHWH came to me'. This again personifies/metaphorizes the divine message as a 'word' that comes.
